pros: Support, flexibility, great incentives and wonderful staff/team/co-workers
cons: No part time benefits available at all

pros: Great intentions, all around. One thing I absolutely love about PRS is that they truly do promote from within. They don't just turn around and terminate you for mistakes but have conversations that allow one to grow in their role and as a person. Hourly employees tend to have the ability to take time off as needed as long as you give supervisors adequate notice.
cons: We don't really have a "say" in changes that are made within the company, even when it affects our department directly. Schedules are very specific and aren't very flexible in salaried roles. Work loads ebb and flow and at times can be extremely overwhelming which can really mess with work-life balance because there is never enough time to complete everything that needs to be done but we need to stay in the 40 hour time limit. Salary should be higher for the work that we do.
None that I can think of.

pros: Flexible hours, schedule changes, low demand
cons: No benefits, no pay time off.

pros: Reliable job and hours, steady income.
cons: Not very many opportunity for promotion and raises
Have to get others to fill in when you need to take off

job_title: Intensive Transition Specialist in Dumfries, VA
pros:
Great Co-Workers
Company seems to care about staff
Teaching some of the classes and working with the clients and many of the staff  is at times very enjoyable.
cons: Upper management seems to think they should emulate a toxic form of corporate culture, even though this is a nonprofit mental health organization. Examples:  Administrators in top 5 positions, at least one of whom has zero clinical background, rake in nearly 6 times the salaries of most other staff (about $250k, which is a matter of public record). Manipulative tactics such as scapegoating and gas lighting abound ("You say that you have been assigned an impossible amount of documentation? Well, how is your time management?" Or:  "You say that your coworker yelled at you and others?  You must be too sensitive." Bullies tend to get rewarded with promotions.  One particular staff member was promoted and then proceeded to either push out or fire a long succession of staff whom they irrationally saw as a threat. Passive aggressiveness and immaturity of those who are put in charge is a glaring problem because it increases frustration and stress levels and also frankly puts clients and staff at risk when there is a crisis.
Micro managers, would joke constantly about callers, rude

review_title: They are so good to their employees
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Fairfax, VA
pros:
I worked primarily for in-home services which means I did not work in an office setting. I love that. 
Excellent work culture. 
CSS team is wonderful. 
Pay was great for first job out of school.
Benefits are great.
Mileage is reimbursed at a good rate.
cons:
If you work in-home services, bed bugs are a possibility. There is no reimbursement for bug extermination.
I enjoyed on the road work, but others may not. You will be in the car quite a bit taking clients to and fro in your own car.

pros: Feeling of accomplishment to help those who call into the hotline, and developing your own skills to better those in crisis.
cons: The constant feeling of shortage. Shortage of staffing, resources, empathy from supervisors.

review_title: NOT BAD BUT NOT GOOD EITHER
